This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 079d72a80e8586e2891ece6fd2d53cff6b7b66f6 into a627cb7cc5d01d146e760cdd1d6f53c22a560531 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-85ac5c7533883b76c2f5465dc7e57bf22406bcdb)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null
This branch has been merged into @upthewaterspout 's https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4830
@jmelchio

Note - it appears on Windows we only run geode-assembly:acceptanceTest, rather than all acceptance tests. @jdeppe-pivotal Is this intentional? 

We reused this docker compose rule because the connector tests use it, but we added to add our test to geode-assembly which is why it actually got run on windows, unlike the rest of the acceptanceTests.
@jmelchio

I'm late to the game, but is there a reason docker compose doesn't work on Windows?  The docs say it can be installed on WIndows server and desktop https://docs.docker.com/compose/install/

Not blocking the PR since it sounds like more work to get docker compose working, just curious
@moleske - I don't know why docker compose doesn't work. You might try asking @smgoller.
the failure in IntegrationTestOpenJDK11 is the known issue GEODE-7901

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 839d25076ae500e2d33d6fbc770da4a0d815aad7 into 578cb0756710cf18ba345e125601e057ec413ebf - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-f2d8b5670693779ab0b8485823c6635f23104bd2)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null

Cool, awesome job.  I'm going to run against some end to end tests and see what else crops up.  Please bear with me.

Also, is there a brief explanation of what was causing the hang and what change was required?  Just for those of us who are curious.

Problem was, that as we are stoping and starting gateway sender, while we are dispatching events, 
in some cases, stopping of gw sender can shutdown ackReaderThread, just after we dispatch batch, so we will never remove this events from queue.

> I don't understand this fix.
> 
> 1. Why do we have to sleep between stopping and restarting the server?
> 2. What does it mean for the new jars to "settle" on the file server?
> 3. If the version was correct before the server stopped, how did it revert to an earlier version after it was restarted?
> 
> Also, I'm hoping for a fix that does not involve a fixed wait. If we didn't do that fixed wait at this spot, would the server eventually pick up the correct version of the jar? If not, why not?

To be honest, I don't quite understand either, but after adding the wait, the test ran more than 100 times without failure, before that, it failed at the 2nd time. Since this is only a test change, and I was hoping to give it a quick fix so that it wouldn't disrupt others PR.
re: GeoDockerAcceptanceTests- could you please create a jira ticket to implement the empty tests, if they are important to implement (or otherwise delete them)?

The `:geode-redis:distributedTest` task has failed twice while running CI for this PR:

```
> Task :geode-redis:distributedTest

org.apache.geode.redis.RedisDistDUnitTest > classMethod FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Suspicious strings were written to the log during this run.
    Fix the strings or use IgnoredException.addIgnoredException to ignore.
    -----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Found suspect string in log4j at line 5300

    [error 2020/03/26 13:30:55.981 GMT <GeodeRedisServer-WorkerThread-3> tid=98] org.apache.geode.ToDataException: toData failed on DataSerializer with id=0 for class class java.util.HashMap
```

The above can be safely ignored while reviewing the changes as this `PR` only adds new `DistributedTests` for the new `clear()` feature on Partition Regions.
@rhoughton-pivot look good?

I think that you set wrong ticket number in commit message, it should be GEODE-7905.
Thanks for the review! Yes I did mis-type the ticket number - glad you picked that up :)

@pivotal-jbarrett the main, unaddressed, issue with the current solution is that calling decode on each key may  break existing users that currently are using keys that contain characters that decode would change to something else. The breaking of backwards compatibility needs to be addressed. Jake's solution appears to address that since it allows us to have keys that contain slashes without needing to decode them. So I'm going to try that out and see how it works.
@kohlmu-pivotal  Thanks for your review mate!

Found this interesting reference - https://netty.io/wiki/reference-counted-objects.html#wiki-h2-9

Yes, I used that setting in order to isolate the leaky code. Longer-running dunits, that produce enough garbage, would probably benefit running under that. Even without that setting, we still see `error` level messages in the logs. (implying that dunit log inspection would find this).
Rolling back the jetty version, it's causing a test failure in `ListIndexManagementDUnitTest.getIndex_fails_when_region_name_is_missing_from_filter`.

All checks were green except rat. I had missed a license file. Just added it so I believe CI will be green on this now.
The distributedTest failure is https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6489.  @kirklund do you have any concerns about merging?

> Some typos and naming suggestions. Also, there is no test confirming the new intended behaviour as described in the JIRA ticket. A test is needed that starts a rebalance, stops and/or starts a member, then confirms that the output of the rebalance command is correct with respect to how many members were actually rebalanced.

As this change doesn't have impacts on functionality of rebalance command just on it's output, I added a test to reproduce a scenario when user list members to see how many server it has, after that do rebalance command which is executed on lower number of servers as one is stopped. After rebalance is completed server is started again and user can see in list member that all members are there and think that rebalance is executed on all of them, but it doesn't. Regarding that new line in rebalance command output is added to be aware how many servers is rebalanced.

@dschneider-pivotal - Is there any underlying technical difference? I had played around with using a `Vector` which, I think, is practically the same thing. The 'lookup' methods still need to have explicit synchronization although the `add` and `remove` don't. Since there is only a single instance of this class in play, having the synchronization at the method level vs at the level of the backing structure also does not make any difference. Although I could buy the argument that that is just how it is currently being used. I think I just convinced myself... :)
I added comments @upthewaterspout. I had to rebase the branch so once the tests run I'll merge.

It only just occurred to me that there should also be some docs changes to go with this, and since the change will be very small, it probably doesn't warrant a separate JIRA ticket. The content in `geode-docs/tools_modules/gfsh/command-pages/rebalance.html.md.erb` should be updated to reflect the new output of the command.
Can you please wait til we sort things out on #4867?  Thanks!
Obsolete
I see some names and details are still being finalized. Friendly reminder: don't forget the docs!

The content in `geode-docs/tools_modules/gfsh/command-pages/rebalance.html.md.erb` should be updated to reflect the new output of the command.
